cards.syntax: SELECT * FROM t1 INNER JOIN t2 ON t1.id = t2.id
cards.description: Returns rows when match exists in both tables
cards.example: SELECT users.name, orders.total FROM users INNER JOIN orders ON users.id = orders.user_id;
cards.explanation: INNER JOIN returns only the rows where there is a match in both tables based on the join condition. Rows without matches are excluded from the result.

cards.syntax: SELECT * FROM t1 LEFT JOIN t2 ON t1.id = t2.id
cards.description: Returns all left table rows plus matched right rows
cards.example: SELECT customers.name, orders.id FROM customers LEFT JOIN orders ON customers.id = orders.customer_id;
cards.explanation: LEFT JOIN returns ALL rows from the left table and matching rows from the right table. If no match, NULL values appear for right table columns.

cards.syntax: SELECT * FROM t1 RIGHT JOIN t2 ON t1.id = t2.id
cards.description: Returns all right table rows plus matched left rows
cards.example: SELECT orders.id, customers.name FROM orders RIGHT JOIN customers ON orders.customer_id = customers.id;
cards.explanation: RIGHT JOIN returns ALL rows from the right table and matching rows from the left table. Opposite of LEFT JOIN - rarely used as LEFT JOIN is more intuitive.

cards.syntax: SELECT * FROM t1 FULL OUTER JOIN t2 ON t1.id = t2.id
cards.description: Returns rows when match exists in either table
cards.example: SELECT employees.name, departments.name FROM employees FULL OUTER JOIN departments ON employees.dept_id = departments.id;
cards.explanation: FULL OUTER JOIN returns all rows from both tables. Matching rows are combined, non-matching rows have NULL for missing columns.

cards.syntax: SELECT * FROM t1 CROSS JOIN t2
cards.description: Returns Cartesian product of two tables
cards.example: SELECT colors.name, sizes.name FROM colors CROSS JOIN sizes;
cards.explanation: CROSS JOIN combines every row from the first table with every row from the second table. If table A has 3 rows and B has 4, result has 12 rows.

cards.syntax: SELECT * FROM table t1 JOIN table t2 ON t1.col = t2.col
cards.example: SELECT e.name, m.name AS manager FROM employees e LEFT JOIN employees m ON e.manager_id = m.id;
cards.explanation: A SELF JOIN is when a table joins to itself. Useful for hierarchical data like employees and managers, or categories with parent categories.

cards.syntax: SELECT * FROM t1 NATURAL JOIN t2
cards.description: Joins tables by columns with same names
cards.example: SELECT * FROM employees NATURAL JOIN departments;
cards.explanation: NATURAL JOIN automatically joins tables based on columns with the same name. Implicit and can be dangerous - explicit JOIN is recommended.

cards.syntax: SELECT * FROM t1 JOIN t2 USING (col_name)
cards.description: Simplifies join when column names match
cards.example: SELECT * FROM orders JOIN order_items USING (order_id);
cards.explanation: USING is a shorthand when both tables have the same column name. Instead of ON t1.id = t2.id, you can write USING (id).

cards.syntax: SELECT * FROM t1 LEFT OUTER JOIN t2 ON t1.id = t2.id
cards.description: Same as LEFT JOIN ( OUTER is optional)
cards.example: SELECT customers.name, orders.id FROM customers LEFT OUTER JOIN orders ON customers.id = orders.customer_id;
cards.explanation: LEFT OUTER JOIN is the same as LEFT JOIN. The OUTER keyword is optional and commonly omitted.

cards.syntax: SELECT * FROM t1, t2 WHERE t1.id = t2.id
cards.example: SELECT * FROM employees, departments WHERE employees.dept_id = departments.id;
cards.explanation: EQUI JOIN uses the equality operator (=) in the join condition. Can use old-style comma syntax with WHERE or modern JOIN with ON.

cards.syntax: SELECT * FROM t1 JOIN t2 ON t1.val BETWEEN t2.min AND t2.max
cards.example: SELECT e.name, s.grade FROM employees e JOIN salary_grades s ON e.salary BETWEEN s.min_sal AND s.max_sal;
cards.explanation: NON-EQUI JOIN uses operators other than = (like <, >, BETWEEN). Useful for range matching, like finding salary grade bands.

cards.syntax: SELECT * FROM t1 JOIN t2 ON ... JOIN t3 ON ...
cards.example: SELECT c.name, o.order_date, i.product FROM customers c JOIN orders o ON c.id = o.customer_id JOIN order_items i ON o.id = i.order_id;
cards.explanation: You can chain multiple JOINs to combine data from many tables. Each JOIN links tables based on their relationships.

cards.description: Join with subquery that references outer query
cards.example: SELECT u.name, top_orders.total FROM users u, LATERAL (SELECT total FROM orders WHERE user_id = u.id ORDER BY total DESC LIMIT 3) top_orders;
cards.explanation: LATERAL allows a subquery to reference columns from tables that appear earlier in the FROM clause. Great for top-N per group queries.
